title: The Article "the" belirtme hali eki
desc: Learn about how to talk about specific things using the article 'the' in Turkish

body.raw: # The article ‚Äúthe‚Äù in Turkish - Belirtme Hali Eki Unlike English, the article ‚Äúthe‚Äù does not come before the noun in Turkish but is rather appended to the noun as a suffix. ‚Üí The suffix we add depends on the **last letter** of the noun. Here is a table to map the ‚Äúthe‚Äù suffix to a noun. ‚Üí if the last letter is **a consonant.** | Last Vowel | Suffix to be added | | --- | --- | | a | **ƒ±** | | e | **i** | | o | **u** | | √º | **√º** | | √∂ | **√º** | ‚Üí If the last letter is **a vowel.** | Last letter | Suffix to be added | | --- | --- | | a | y**ƒ±** | | e | y**i** | | o | y**u** | | √º | y**√º** | | √∂ | y**√º** | üìå If the last letter is a **vowel** then ‚Äúy‚Äù comes in between as a mediator between the two vowels. In Turkish two vowels do not come together back to back. It is one of the golden rules of Turkish. Words that have two consecutive vowels are **loanwords** Examples √áay ‚Üí Tea, √áay**ƒ±** ‚Üí the tea Ev ‚Üí House, Ev**i** ‚Üí the house Balkon ‚Üí Balcony, Balkon**u** ‚Üí the balcony G√ºl ‚Üí Rose, G√ºl**√º** ‚Üí the rose G√∂l ‚Üí Lake, G√∂l**√º** ‚Üí the lake Examples: Araba ‚Üí Car, Arabay**ƒ±** ‚Üí the car Sebze ‚Üí Vegetable, Sebzey**i** ‚Üí the vegetable Depo ‚Üí Warehouse, Depoy**u** ‚Üí the warehouse K√∂t√º ‚Üí Bad, K√∂t√ºy**√º** ‚Üí the bad --- Thanks for reading!

title: From -dan -den -tan -ten suffix in Turkish
desc: The equivalent of From in Turkish explained

body.raw:
# From (-dan -den -tan -ten) Ayrƒ±lma Hali Eki

In Turkish, "from" is a suffix that can be -**dan**, -**den**, -**tan**, -**ten**. 

You might think, so do I have to remember all of these? The good answer is not at all. They are basically the same thing and have a formula.

Previously, we saw the **f,s,t,k,√ß,≈ü,h,p** and vowel harmony. These two are one of the core principles of the Turkish grammar.

| Last Vowel  | Last Letter | From |
| --- | --- | --- |
| a-ƒ±-o-u | one of `[ f, s, t, k, √ß, ≈ü, h, p ]` | -**tan** |
| a-ƒ±-o-u | one of `[ other letters ]` | -**dan** |
| e-i-√∂-√º | one of `[ f, s, t, k, √ß, ≈ü, h, p ]` | -**ten** |
| e-i-√∂-√º | one of `[ other letters ]` | -**den** |

`other letters` - a, b, c, d, e, g, ƒü, ƒ±, i, j, l, m, n, o, √∂, r, u, √º, v, y, z.

Examples:

- **from** distance‚Üí uzak**tan**
- **from** Europe ‚Üí Avrupa'**dan**
- **from** the office ‚Üí ofis**ten**
- **from** Turkey ‚ÜíT√ºrkiye'**den**

   

When using the word 'from' in sentences like:

- I am coming **from** the hospital ‚áí Ben hastane**den** geliyorum.

     *hastane* ‚Üí *hospital* üè•

- He is **from** Palermo  . ‚áí O Palermo‚Äô**dan**dƒ±r.

You add -dan, -den, -tan or -ten based on the ending of the noun or verb. It shows leaving a place or belonging to a group just like you use 'from' in English.

 The -DAn suffix doesn‚Äôt exclusively describe belonging or source. It can also express other things based on the context. If you want to know look at the sentence below.

‚ÄúI am asking **out of** curiosity‚Äù translates to ‚Äúmerak**tan** soruyorum‚Äù

üìå Two things to know for now would be

 1.  There is no one to one relation between English and Turkish grammar.

1. Turkish by design express a lot with few in comparison to English and does it because suffixes can have multiple functions and are powerful in combination.

---
Thanks for reading!

title: How To Get Started With Learning Turkish
desc: You can always learn a foreign language, it is an adventure and worthy of taking on

body.raw:
# How to get started: Learning Turkish

One of the hurdles of learning a new language is not knowing where to get started. In this writing I cover what I would do if I was to start and learn Turkish all over again. Stay tuned!

First of all let me talk about the mental model required that more or less applies to learning any language.


### 1. Approach with a mindset of a five year old.

You can apply this approach in order to learn the alphabet of the the language and basic words like `car, apple, tree, socks, jacket, chair, table...` and the like.

<aside>
üîë One thing you should pay attention to learn or ask(if you have someone) as many questions as possible and **map** this words to the language you are comfortable with the most.

</aside>

Coming back to Turkish, learn daily used words and associate the context of how you learned it. Eventually you would forget and re-learn words but you know the words you will not forget, the words you remember how you came to learn them. 

To illustrate this,

> On my first night in Turkey, I learned `hot` in Turkish was `sƒ±cak (/s…Ø.Ààd í…ëk/)` when I was offered a hot tea. Intuitively `cold` follows as soƒüuk.
> 

From the above example I can introduce some things about Turkish.

1. There is a letter `ƒ±` ‚Üí `‚Äúi‚Äù without the dot`  
2. The letter `c` in Turkish  is like the `j` in English.
3. Whenever you see `ƒü` ‚Üí ‚Äúsoft `g`‚Äú, read the word like `ƒü` did not exist. Just ignore it. 

<aside>
üîë A popular example to see the above three concepts in action leads as to look at the name of The president of T√ºrkiye.
His name is usually mispronounced by international journalist. 
Re**c**ep Tayyip Erdo**ƒü**an ‚Üí It is pronounced as ‚ÄúRe**j**eb Tayyip Erdo**_**an‚Äù

</aside>

---

### 2. What is Turkish actually Like?

Turkish is an agglutinative language. The word agglutinative comes from the Latin verb ùò¢ùò®ùò®ùò≠ùò∂ùòµùò™ùòØùò¢ùò≥ùò¶ meaning to glue together. Words in Turkish generally have a root and a suffix. The suffix determines the tense, or whether if it is a verb or a noun.

So you can approach learning Turkish like solving a jigsaw puzzle.

---


### 3. Back to the root

Most of the thing you do when learning Turkish is visually breaking down words to their basic constituents ‚Äî the root and the suffix(s).  

<aside>
üìù Let us see this in play, 

The sentence ‚ÄúYou will learn Turkish‚Äù translates to ‚ÄúSiz T√ºrk√ße √∂ƒürenecksiniz.‚Äù

Siz ‚Üí You
T√ºrk√ße ‚Üí Turkish 
‚Äî *You see Turkish came before the verb ‚Äúto learn‚Äù ‚Üí The sentence structure in Turkish  is  ‚Äî Subject + Object + Verb* 
√ñƒüreneceksiniz ‚Üí You will learn

</aside>

Let us break ‚Äú√∂ƒürenecksiniz‚Äù into its root and suffixes.

- What is the verb in the first place?
    - **√∂ƒürenmek (to learn)**
     Verbs in Turkish have the ending ‚Äú**mak or mek**‚Äù after the **root.**
- What is the root of the verb?
    - **√∂ƒüren (learn)**
        
        You get the **root** by removing the **‚Äúmak or mek‚Äù** from the **verb.**
        
- The suffixes.
    - -ecek
        - It makes it future tense
    - -siniz
        - It ends with siniz since it started with Siz(**plural you**) it has to end in a way that is in **agreement** with the **Subject**( Siz ‚Üí You üôÉ). 
        Siz T√ºrk√ße √∂ƒüreneceksiniz ‚Üí  You will learn Turkish

<aside>
üìå You can be overwhelmed by the above example ‚Äî what I say to you making such dissections only makes sense after learning about verbs, tenses and building good library of words.

</aside>

<aside>
üìå I want you to know like many things in Life **Turkish grammar** also makes sense in **hindsight**. You enjoy it coming back understanding why it had to be that way. The above example is just to help you find out if you find the challenge interesting enough to learn more.

</aside>

---

Thanks for `reading`!

# At - locative suffix -DA  Bulunma Hali Eki

Generally to express physical location, action, object or context in Turkish the suffixes -**da** or -**de** is added to the word.

<aside>
üí° 
Examples

**At** home ‚Äî ev****de****       
**At** library ‚Äî  k√ºt√ºphane**de
At** the cinema ‚Äî Sinema**da
In** T√ºrkiye   ‚Äî  T√ºrkiye‚Äô****de
On**** Tuesday ‚Äî Salƒ±****da****

üìå Proper nouns have apostrophe( **‚Äô** ) before the suffix as
******** 
***Proper nouns*** - *a specific name for a particular person, place, or thing*

</aside>

              ********

If the last letter of the word is one of the letters [ **f**, **s**, **t**, **k**, **√ß**, **≈ü**, **h**, **p** ], then the locative suffix is
 -******ta****** or -****te.****

üçä Tip ‚ûñ You can easily remember the letters by memorizing it as ‚Äú**fƒ±stƒ±k√ßƒ±≈üƒ±hap**‚Äù.

<aside>
üí° 
Examples

**At** office ‚Äî ofis****te****
**At** Park ‚Äî park****ta****
**At** 
**On** boat ‚Äî bot****ta****
**On** airplane ‚Äî u√ßak**ta**
**In** February ‚Äî ≈ûubat**ta**

</aside>

Why do we have **-da** and **-de**?

- It is because of `vowel harmony`. If the last vowel of the word is either `a-ƒ±-o-u` ‚Üí d**a**,
if it is `e-i-√∂-√º` ‚Üí d**e.**

Why do we have **-ta** and **-te**?

- It is for the ease of pronunciation. Try saying u√ßak**da**  and u√ßak**ta.** Which one was easier to say? When using **-ta** or **-ta** it becomes softer to say. Less friction üòé.
- Vowel harmony also applies here to determine whether is is -t**a** or -t**e.**

---
Thanks for reading and remember **fƒ±stƒ±k√ßƒ±≈üƒ±hap.**

title: Plural form -lar and -ler in Turkish
desc: Plural form of nouns in Turkish

body.raw:
# Plurals in Turkish - √áokluk Eki --- Let us take a look at how we can make words plural. It is the same like English in the sense that it comes at the end of the word. The letters that correspond to `s` , `es` or `ies` in English for plurality are **lar** and ********ler.******** Let us see this in play.
üí° Car ‚Üí Car**s** Flower ‚Üí Flowers Araba ‚Üí Araba******lar****** √ái√ßek ‚Üí √ái√ßek******ler******
You might be wondering when do we use **************ler************** and when do we use **********lar**********? In Turkish, for ease of pronunciation we pay attention to the **last vowel** of the word being in harmony with the **suffix** added.
üí° üìå If the last vowel is either `a` , `ƒ±` ,`o` ,`u` then ********lar******** is added to the word to make it plural. üìå If the last vowel is either `e`, `i`, `√∂` `√º` then **ler** is added to the word to make it plural.
| Last Vowel | Plural suffix | | --- | --- | | a-ƒ±-o-u | -**lar** | | e-i-√∂-√º | -**ler** | That‚Äôs why Cars is Araba**lar** and Flowers is √ái√ßek******ler.****** ### Using ‚Äúler‚Äù and ‚Äúlar‚Äù with Numbers When a word is preceded by a number in Turkish, we **do not** use the suffixes -**lar** and -**ler.**
üí° Five Books ‚Üí Be≈ü kitaplar ‚ùå ‚Üí Be≈ü kitap ‚úÖ Why is that? It is because the number **be≈ü** is already indicates its plural and to avoid redundancy.
üìå You will probably be like d√∂rt arabalar when you should instead say d√∂rt araba.It takes conscious effort to avoid it. --- Thanks for reading!

title: Simple past tense -DI and -DU explained
desc: Learn about the suffix of past tense in Turkish

body.raw:
## Simple past tense -DI and -DU (Belirtili Ge√ßmi≈ü Zaman) --- Simple past tense in Turkish is actually very simple :). The suffix that is used in the past tense of nouns, verbs or an adjectives is -**DI** or -**DU**. - **D** ‚Üí `d` or `t` (The **f-s-t-k-√ß-≈ü-h-p** rule) - **I** ‚Üí `ƒ±` or `i` (Vowel harmony i.e ease of pronunciation) - **U** ‚Üí `u` or `√º` (Vowel harmony i.e ease of pronunciation)

Don‚Äôt be overwhelmed by this formula. The image below explains it all.

üìù *The ‚Äò**d**‚Äô becomes ‚Üí ‚Äò**t**‚Äô when the last letter is one of the **f-s-t-k-√ß-≈ü-h-p**.* ### Examples

1. Verbs

| Turkish Verb | English Verb | Past Tense (3rd Person Singular) | English | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Gelmek | To come | Gel**di** | came | | Gitmek | To go | Git**ti** | went | | Zƒ±plamak | To jump | Zƒ±pla**dƒ±** | jumped | | Yapmak | To do | Yap**tƒ±** | did | | Uyumak | To sleep | Uyu**du** | slept | | G√ºlmek | To laugh | G√ºl**d√º** | laughed | - üü© - root of verb - üü® - indicator of verb (All verbs in Turkish end with `mak` or `mek`) - üü• - past tense suffix - üü¶ - last letter of root ---

2. Adjectives

| Turkish Adjective | English Adjective | Past Tense (3rd Person Singular) | English | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | B√ºy√ºk | Big | B√ºy√ºk**t√º** | It was big | | K√º√ß√ºk | Small | K√º√ß√ºk**t√º** | It was small | | Yeni | New | Yeniy**di** | It was new | | Eski | Old | Eskiy**di** | It was old | | G√ºzel | Beautiful | G√ºzel**di** | It was beautiful | | ƒ∞yi | Good | ƒ∞yiy**di** | It was good | - üü¶ - last letter of word - üüß - separator 'y' between two vowels (only in noun and adjective), **not** in verbs ‚ùå. - üü• - past tense suffix ---

3. Nouns

| Turkish Noun | English Noun | Past Tense (3rd Person Singular) | English Translation | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Masa | Table | ‚Ä¶g√ºzel masay**dƒ±**. | It was beautiful table | | Resim | Picture | ‚Ä¶b√ºy√ºk resim**di**. | It was big picture | | Arkada≈ü | Friend | ‚Ä¶samimi arkada≈ü**tƒ±**. | He/she was sincere friend | | ≈ûehir | City | ‚Ä¶b√ºy√ºk ≈üehir**di**. | It was big city | | Yemek | Food | ‚Ä¶lezzetli yemek**ti**. | It was delicious food | | M√ºzik | Music | ...harika m√ºzik**ti**. | It was great music | --- ‚ôüÔ∏è If the last letter of the word a **noun** or an **adjective** is a **vowel,** ‚Äòy‚Äô comes in between as a separator. ‚ôüÔ∏è There is also a non suffix way of expressing past tense by using the word **idi** after a noun and adjective. - ‚ôüÔ∏è Example would be g√ºzel**di** ‚Üí g√ºzel **idi**, durust**tu** ‚Üí durust **idi**. - In this case **no need** to consider `vowel harmony` or `f-s-t-k-√ß-≈ü-h-p` rules, just add **idi** to any noun or adjective. --- Thanks for reading!

title: This That Here There - Bu ≈ûu O Burada ≈ûurada Orada
desc: Learn how to describe things using this that here and there in Turkish

body.raw:
# This, That, Here and There in Turkish
---

## This and That


Want to learn how to say "this" and "that" in Turkish?

In Turkish, we use '**bu**' for '**this**'. We  also interchangeably use **≈üu** for ‚Äò**this**‚Äô as well. ‚Äú**This**‚Äù in Turkish depends on how close or far you are from what you're describing.

Imagine you are at the beach and want to describe what you see. If you want to talk about the sand "**This** is sand" would be "**bu** k√ºmd√ºr". 

When talking about something closer like the water nearby, you would use '**≈üu**', as in ‚Äú**≈üu** denizdir‚Äù (**this** is a sea). If you are referring to something far like the sun, it would be appropriate to use ‚Äò**o**‚Äô, so "**that** is the sun" would be ‚Äú**o** g√ºne≈ütir‚Äù.

<Image 
src="/images/A1/Unit-1/Bu-Su-O.png"
fill 
alt="Bu Su O explainer image of a beach"
 />
 ---

<aside>
üí° 

To describe things very close to us we use '**bu**/********this********', for things near us we use ‚Äò**≈üu**/********that********‚Äô, and for things at a distance we use ‚Äò**o**/**that**‚Äô.

Technically both ‚Äô**≈üu**‚Äô and ‚Äô**o**‚Äô are equivalent to ‚Äò**that**‚Äô, but their use changes based on **proximity** to what is being described.

</aside>

# Here and There


Turkish is a logical language with few surprises and predictable structure unlike English. We'll build on what we've learned to learn about 'here' and 'there'.

Everything connects in Turkish. It is pretty much like building with LEGO bricks. We have seen that 'this' is "bu" and that' can be either "≈üu" or "o".Now to spice things up adding the suffix "**rada**" changes **this** to **here** and **that** to **there**.

When adding `rada` to this(`bu`) it becomes here (`burada`), by the same token `there` becomes `≈üurada`, and or `there(far)` ‚Üí `orada`.

So if someone asks where they should sit, you can say either **burada**(here)**, ≈üurada**(there) ****or **orada**(there(far)).

<aside>
üí°

 Add the suffix ‚Äú**rada**‚Äù to **bu**, **≈üu**, or **o** to indicate location.
 **burada** ‚Üí here 
 **≈üurada**  ‚Üí there
 **orada**   ‚Üí there(far)

</aside>

# Burada vs Burasƒ±


### What is the difference?

> **Burada** ‚Üí is used to describe a location point. 
******************Burasƒ± ‚Üí****************** refers to specific area or vicinity.

üí° **If** burada ************************is a point,************************ burasƒ± **********************is an area.**********************
> 

<Image 
src="/images/A1/Unit-1/Burasi_explained.png"
fill
alt="Bu Su O explainer image of a beach"
 /> 
 ---




###### I hope that has clarified things. See you in the next post!

---

title: Var and Yok explained
desc: Expressing possession or existence of things in Turkish

body.raw:
# Have and Don‚Äôt Have in Turkish
---

Let's talk about expressing possession in Turkish, using the words '**var**' and '**yok**'. These two crucial words indicate whether you have or don't have something. They typically come **at the end** of a sentence.

To understand their meanings, '**var**' translates to "**exists**", while '**yok**' means "**doesn't exist**". So when you say you own something in Turkish, you are literally saying it exists. The **pronoun** is where **ownership** is expressed with **suffix**.

For example, if you want to express that you have a car in Turkish, you'd say "benim arabam var." Here, 'var' confirms that the car exists for you. But if there isn‚Äôt any car for your disposal then it would be expressed as ‚Äúbenim arabam yok.‚Äù

<aside>
üí° The logic of Turkish is like
‚ÄùBen**im** araba**m** ***var***‚Äù ‚Üí literal translation ‚ÄúMy car exists‚Äù
 Actually means ‚Üí I have a car. 

My car exists == I have a car.

</aside>

In these sentences ‚Äòben‚Äô stands for I and by adding suffix ‚Äòim‚Äô we get benim which is My (mine). Similarly ,car is araba in turkish but to show that its yours we add ‚Äòm‚Äô making it araba**m**.

<aside>
üí° You may say I get ben**im** but why do we have to add suffix to the car and say araba**m.**
Shouldn‚Äôt a car be just be a car everywhere regardless of how it is used in a sentence?

At this level, I want you to look at it this way. 
Whenever you add a suffix to a Pronoun(Ben, sen, o, siz, biz), you are saying I have initiated sth so the way to finish it is with another appropriate closer.

When I say Ben****im****, I initiated a relationship so I will close it with some closer suffix.
So Ben**im** araba****m,**** Sen**in** ev**in**, O**nun** ev**i**

Think of it like opening and closing a parenthesis. ( ). If you open then you have to close it.


</aside>

> In Turkish language structure matters especially towards the end where key meaning lies with either ‚Äú**var**‚Äù denoting existence thus confirming possession or ‚Äú**yok**‚Äù indicating non-existence hence clarifying lack of possession.
> 

So if you are the type that sometimes hums the end a word or sentence when you are not sure, Turkish will not let that slide üöß.  

---

title: To -a -e -ya -ye suffix in Turkish
desc: The equivalent of to in Turkish explained

body.raw:
# To - Y√∂nelme Hal Eki

When trying to understanding the dynamics of Turkish one thing that is peculiar is how suffixes come between words to relate or bind them just like mortar is for bricks.

When ever there is a direction is involved as in going to some where, or the flow action from one to another. We have the suffixes **-A.** 

<aside>
üí° It is like ‚Äò**to‚Äô** in English.

</aside>

 

| Last Vowel | To |
| --- | --- |
| a-ƒ±-o-u | **a** |
| e-i-√∂-√º | **e** |

‚ö†Ô∏è One thing to pay attention to is if the **last letter** is **a** or **e.** In general no two vowels come next to each other in Turkish so we have to add a mediator **********y********** in between.

car ‚Üí araba

‚Ä¶**to** the car ‚Üí araba + a = araba**a**     ‚ùå

‚Ä¶**to** the car ‚Üí araba + a = araba**ya**   ‚úÖ

### Let us see some more examples

‚Ä¶**to** school ‚Üí okul**a**

‚Ä¶**to** the cinema ‚Üí sinema****ya****

‚Ä¶**to** the park ‚Üí park**a**

‚Ä¶**to** America ‚Üí Amerika‚Äô**ya** ( We separate with apostrophe for proper names )

‚Ä¶**to** Kenya ‚Üí Kenya‚Äô****ya****

‚Ä¶**to** Library ‚Üí K√ºt√ºphane‚Äô**ye** 

### Let use it in a sentence

Ben okul**a** gidiyorum ‚áí I go **to** school.

Sen sinema**ya** gidiyorsun ‚áí You go **to** the cinema.

O park**a** gidiyor ‚áí He/She goes **to** the park.

Biz Amerika‚Äô**ya** gidiyoruz ‚áí We go **to** America.

Siz Kenya‚Äô**ya** gidiyorsunuz ‚áí You go **to** Kenya.

Onlar K√ºt√ºphane‚Äô**ye** gidiyorlar ‚áí They go **to** the library.

> Don‚Äôt worry about the verb used in above and why it has different endings. Focus on how the suffix ****a**** and ****e**** are used to express the direction or flow of action is.

This is one of the most important suffixes in the Turkish language and powerful in expressing things when used in combination with other words.
> 

 

---

Thanks for reading!
